Gothic War in Italy as a part of Justinian's Reconquest.
Byzantines retook Italy but crippled the Byzantine economy and left Italy unable to cope against the oncoming Lombards.
Saint Columba founds mission in Iona.
Constructed an abbey which helped convert the Picts to Christianity until it was destroyed and raided by the Vikings in 794.
The Kingdom of the Lombards is founded in Italy.
Survived in Italy until the invasion of the Franks in 774 under Charlemagne.
Muhammad is born.
Professed receiving revelations from God, which were recorded in the Qur'an, the basis of Islamic theology, in which he is regarded as the last of the sent prophets.
The West Saxons continue their advance at the Battle of Deorham.
Led to the permanent separation of Cornwall, England from Wales.
Sui Dynasty in China.
March 4—May 23
China unified once again during this period for the first time in almost 400 years.
Gregory the Great becomes Pope.
September 3
The missionary work reached new levels during his pontificate, revolutionized the way of worship for the Catholic Church (Gregorian Chants), liturgy, etc., and was soon canonized after his death.
Augustine arrives in Kent.
Christianization of England (Anglo-Saxons) begins.
Massive Chinese (Sui and Tang) invasions against Korean Goguryeo.
Contributed to the fall of the Sui Dynasty, and Goguryeo fell under the forces of the Tang and Silla.
Last great Roman-Persian War.
Long conflict leaves both empires exhausted and unable to cope with the newly united Arab armies under Islam in the 630s
Grand Canal in China is fully completed
Its main role throughout its history was the transport of grain to the capital.
Tang Dynasty in China.
June 18—June 1
The essential administrative system of this dynasty lasts for 286 years.
Muhammad Migrates from Mecca to Medina.
9 September— 23 September
Event will have designated first year of the Islamic Calendar, as Anno Hegirae.
Joint Persian-Avar-Slav Siege of Constantinople Constantinople saved, Avar power broken and Persians henceforth on the defensive
Joint Persian-Avar-Slav Siege of Constantinople Constantinople saved, Avar power broken and Persians henceforth on the defensive
Battle of Nineveh.
December 12
The Byzantines, under Heraclius, crush the Persians.
Death of Muhammad.
June 8
By this point, all of Arabia is Muslim.
Accession of Abu Bakr as first Caliph.
June 8
Though the period of his caliphate was not long, it included successful invasions of the two most powerful empires of the time.
Battle of Heavenfield.
Northumbrian army under Oswald defeat Welsh army.
Jerusalem captured by the Arab army, mostly Muslims, but with contingents of Syrian Christians.Muslims.
Jerusalem captured by the Arab army, mostly Muslims, but with contingents of Syrian Christians.Muslims.
Battle of Nehawand. Muslims conquer Persia.
Battle of Nehawand. Muslims conquer Persia.
Arab Army led by Omar Ibn Al-'Aas takes Alexandria.
Arab Army led by Omar Ibn Al-'Aas takes Alexandria.
In Japan, the Soga clan falls.
This initiates a period of imitation of Chinese culture, The Nara period begins a year later.
Slav occupation of Balkans complete.
Slav occupation of Balkans complete.
Synod of Whitby.
Roman Christianity triumphs over Celtic Christianity in England.
Ends of the Three Kingdoms period in Korea.
Established a Unified Silla which led to the North South States Period 30 years later.
First Arab siege of Constantinople.
First time Islamic armies defeated, forestalling Islamic conquest of Europe.
Establishment of the Bulgarian Empire.
A country with great influence in the European history in the Middle Ages.
Battle of Dun Nechtain. Picts defeat Northumbrians, whose dominance ends.
Battle of Dun Nechtain. Picts defeat Northumbrians, whose dominance ends.
Battle of Tertry
Established Pepin of Herstal as mayor over the entire realms of Neustria and Austrasia, which further dwindled Merovingian power.
Arab army takes Carthage.
End of Byzantine rule in North Africa
North South States Period begins in Korea.
Silla and Balhae coexisted in the south and north of the peninsula, respectively, until 926
Muslims - Arabs and Berbers, under Tariq Ibn Zeyad Tarik invade the Iberian peninsula.
Will begin a period of Muslim rule within in the Iberian peninsula (with various portions of land) until nearly the end of the Fifteenth Century.
Second Arab attack on Constantinople, ending in failure. The combined Byzantine–Bulgarian forces stop the Arab threat in Southeastern Europe.
Second Arab attack on Constantinople, ending in failure. The combined Byzantine–Bulgarian forces stop the Arab threat in Southeastern Europe.
Iconoclast movement begun in the Byzantine Empire under Leo III. This was opposed by Pope Gregory II, and an important difference between the Roman and Byzantine churches.
Iconoclast movement begun in the Byzantine Empire under Leo III. This was opposed by Pope Gregory II, and an important difference between the Roman and Byzantine churches.
Battle of Tours. Charles Martel halts Muslim advance.
October
Significant moment that led to the forming of the Carolingian Empire for the Franks, and halted the advancement of the Moors in southwestern Europe.
Death of Bede.
26 May
Bede was later regarded as "the father of English history"
Beginning of Abbasid Caliphate.
25 January
Would become the longest lasting caliphate, until 1519 when conquered and annexed into the Ottoman Empire.
Pepin the Short founds the Carolingian dynasty.
Pepin the Short founds the Carolingian dynasty.
Pepin promises the Pope central Italy. This is arguably the beginning of the temporal power of the Papacy.
Pepin promises the Pope central Italy. This is arguably the beginning of the temporal power of the Papacy.
Beginning of Charlemagne's reign.
Battle of Roncevaux Pass.
15 August
Battle of Roncevaux Pass.
Accession of Harun al-Rashid to the Caliphate in Baghdad.
14 September
Accession of Harun al-Rashid to the Caliphate in Baghdad.
Sack of Lindisfarne. Viking attacks on Britain begin.
Generally considered the beginning of the Viking Age that would span over two centuries, and reach as far south as Hispania and as far east as the Byzantine Empire, and present day Russia.
Heian period in Japan.
Considered to be the last classical period of History of Japan. Chinese influence was at its strongest during this era in Japan.
Death of Offa.
29 July
Marks the end of Mercian dominance in England.
Charlemagne is crowned Holy Roman Emperor.
25 December
With his crowning, Charlemagne's kingdom is officially recognized by the Papacy as the largest in Europe since the fall of the Roman Empire.
Gunpowder was invented (somewhere around 9th century)
Gunpowder was invented (somewhere around 9th century)
Death of Charlemagne.
28 January
Would be a factor towards the splitting of his empire almost 30 years later.
Battle of Ellandun. Egbert defeats Mercians.
Wessex becomes the leading kingdom of England.
Muslims invade Sicily.
First encounter of attempts to conquer Byzantine Sicily, until the last Byzantine outpost was conquered in 965.
Muslims capture Bari and much of southern Italy.
Muslims capture Bari and much of southern Italy.
Division of Charlemagne's Empire between his grandsons with the Treaty of Verdun.
Sets the stage for the founding of the Holy Roman Empire and France as separate states.
Kenneth McAlpin becomes king of the Picts and Scots, creating the Kingdom of Alba.
Kenneth McAlpin becomes king of the Picts and Scots, creating the Kingdom of Alba.
Viking state in Russia founded under Rurik, first at Novgorod, then Kiev.
Viking state in Russia founded under Rurik, first at Novgorod, then Kiev.
Christianization of Bulgaria.
Fujiwara period in Japan.
Would become the most powerful clan during the Heian period in Japan for around three centuries.
Viking "Great Army" arrives in England.
Northumbria, East Anglia, and Mercia were overwhelmed.
Earliest known printed book in China with a date.
Earliest known printed book in China with a date.
Alfred the Great assumes the throne, the first king of a united England.
He defended England from Viking invaders, formed new laws and fostered a rebirth of religious and scholarly activities.
Harold Fairhair becomes King of Norway.
Harold Fairhair becomes King of Norway.
Iceland is settled by Norsemen.
Iceland is settled by Norsemen.
Kievan Rus' is established.
Would be sustained until the Mongol invasion of Rus' over four and a half centuries, despite peaking during the middle 11th century during the reign of Yaroslav the Wise.
Arrival of the disciples of Saints Cyril and Methodius in Bulgaria
Creation of the Cyrillic script; in the following decades the country became the cultural and spiritual centre of the whole Eastern Orthodox part of the Slavic World.
Vikings attack Paris.
Vikings attack Paris.
Simeon I becomes ruler of the First Bulgarian Empire in the Balkans.
Simeon I becomes ruler of the First Bulgarian Empire in the Balkans.
Arpad and the Magyars are present in Pannonia.
Arpad and the Magyars are present in Pannonia.
Death of Alfred the Great.
26 October
Death of Alfred the Great.
Mayan Empire collapses
Tang Dynasty ends with Emperor Ai deposed.
The Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms period in China commences.
King Edward the Elder of England, son of King Alfred, defeats the Northumbrian Vikings at the Battle of Tettenhall; they never raid south of the River Humber again.
Cluny Abbey is founded by William I, Count of Auvergne.
Cluny goes on to become the acknowledged leader of Western Monasticism. Cluniac Reforms initiated with the abbey's founding.
The Viking Rollo and his tribe settle in what is now Normandy by the terms of the Treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Epte, founding the Duchy of Normandy.
Battle of Anchialus. Simeon I the Great defeats the Byzantines.
Recognition of the Imperial Title of the Bulgarian rulers.
Henry the Fowler, Duke of Saxony elected German King. First king of the Ottonian Dynasty.
Henry I considered the founder and first king of the medieval German state.
The first King of Croatia (rex Croatorum), Tomislav (910–928) of the Trpimirović dynasty was crowned.
Tomislav united Croats of Dalmatia and Pannonia into a single Kingdom, and created a sizeable state.
King Aethelstan the Glorious unites the heptarchy of The Anglo-Saxon nations of Wessex,Sussex, Essex, Kent, East Anglia, Mercia and Northumbria founding the Kingdom of England.
King Aethelstan the Glorious unites the heptarchy of The Anglo-Saxon nations of Wessex,Sussex, Essex, Kent, East Anglia, Mercia and Northumbria founding the Kingdom of England.
According to Theophanes Continuatus (The Continuer of Theophanes's Chronicle) - Tomislav of Croatia defeated Bulgarian army of Tsar Simeon I under Duke Alogobotur, in battle of the Bosnian Highlands.
Bulgarian expansion to the west was stopped.
Death of Simeon I the Great. Recognition of the Bulgarian Patriarchate, the first independent National Church in Europe.
Abd-ar-Rahman III of the Umayyad dynasty in al-Andalus (part of the Iberian peninsula) takes the title of Caliph or ruler of the Islamic world.
Beginning of the Caliphate of Córdoba (929-1031).
Wang Geon unified Later Three Kingdoms of Korea.
Battle of Lechfeld. Otto the Great, son of Henry the Fowler, defeats the Magyars.
This is the defining event that prevents the Hungarians from entering Central Europe.
Mieszko I becomes duke of Polans.
First historical ruler of Poland and de facto founder of the Polish State.
Song Dynasty begins after Emperor of Taizu usurps the throne from the Later Zhou, last of the Five Dynasties.
A 319-year period of Song rule (Northern & Southern combined) goes underway.
Otto the Great crowned the Holy Roman Emperor.
First to be crowned Holy Roman Emperor in nearly 40 years.
Otto deposes Pope John XII who is replaced with Pope Leo VIII.
Citizens of Rome promise not to elect another Pope without Imperial approval.
Mieszko I of Poland and his court embrace Christianity, which becomes national religion.
Mieszko I of Poland and his court embrace Christianity, which becomes national religion.
John I Tzimiskes the last Byzantium empire and Nikephoros II are being executed.
Sultane of Rums are proclaim.
Death of John I Tzimiskes; Basil II (his co-emperor) takes sole power.
Under Basil II zenith of the power of Eastern Empire after Justinian.
Al-Mansur Ibn Abi Aamir becomes de facto ruler of Muslim Al-Andalus.
Peak of power of Moorish Iberia under "Almanzor".
Basil II (called "Bulgar Slayer") begins final conquest of Bulgaria by Eastern Empire.
Conquest finished by 1018.
Eric the Red, exiled from Iceland, begins Scandinavian colonization of Greenland.
Eric the Red, exiled from Iceland, begins Scandinavian colonization of Greenland.
Succession of Hugh Capet to the French Throne.
Beginning of Capetian Dynasty.
Volodymyr I of Kiev embrace Christianity, which becomes national religion.
Volodymyr I of Kiev embrace Christianity, which becomes national religion.
Peace and Truce of God formed.
The first movement of the Catholic Church using spiritual means to limit private war, and the first movement in medieval Europe to control society through non-violent means.
Leif Ericson is to settle during the winter in present-day Canada at L'Anse aux Meadows.
Ericson is to be the first European to settle in the Americas during the Norse exploration of the Americas.
Canute the Great becomes King of England after the death of Edmund Ironside, with whom he shared the English throne.
Danes become kings of England for the next 26 years before the last rise of the Anglo-Saxons before the Norman Conquest.
The Byzantines under Basil II conquer Bulgaria after a bitter 50-years struggle.
Concludes the Byzantine conquest of Bulgaria.
The Tale of Genji, written by Murasaki Shikibu, is completed sometime before this date.
It is sometimes called the world's first novel, the first modern novel, the first psychological novel or the first novel still to be considered a classic.
The Great Seljuk Empire is founded by Tughril Beg.
Would be a major force during the first two Crusades, and an antagonist to the Byzantine Empire over the next century...
Pope Leo IX ascends to the papal throne.
Leo IX was the pope that excommunicated Patriarch of Constantinople, Michael Cerularius (who also excommunicated Leo), which caused the Great Schism.
The astrolabe, an ancient tool of navigation, is first used in Europe.
Early tool of marine navigators, astrologers, astronomers.
The East-West Schism which divided the church into Western Catholicism and Eastern Orthodoxy.
Tensions will vary between the Catholic and Orthodox churches throughout the Middle Ages.
William the Conqueror, Duke of Normandy, invades England and becomes King after the Battle of Hastings.
End of Anglosaxon rule in England and start of Norman lineage.
Pope Gregory VII elevated to the papal throne.
This begins a period of church reform.
The Seljuks under Alp Arslan defeat the Byzantine army at Manzikert. The Normans capture Bari, the last Byzantine possession in southern Italy.
Beginning of the end of Byzantine rule in Asia Minor.
Dictatus Papae in which Pope Gregory VII defines the powers of the pope.
Peak of the Gregorian Reform, and an immense factor in the Investiture Controversy.
Holy Roman Emperor Henry IV walks to Canossa where he stands barefoot in the snow to beg forgiveness of the Pope for his offences, and admitting defeat in the Investiture Controversy.
This helps establish Papal rule over European heads of state for another 450 years.
The Construction of the Tower of London begins.
The tower of London was the ultimate keep of the British Empire.
The compilation of the Domesday Book, a great land and property survey commissioned by William the Conqueror to assess his new possessions.
This is the first such undertaking since Roman times.
University of Bologna is formed.
It is the oldest university in Europe.
Pope Urban issues the Crusades to capture the Holy Land, and to repel the Seljuk Turks from the Byzantine Empire from Alexios I Komnenos.
This would be the first of 9 Major Crusades, and a number of other crusades that would spread into the late 13th century.
First Crusade. Jerusalem is re-taken from the Muslims on the urging of Pope Urban II.
This would lead to the beginning of the Kingdom of Jerusalem, which would last for nearly two centuries; within the era of the Crusades to the Holy Land.
The Cistercian Order is founded.
Was a return to the original observance of the Rule of St. Benedict.

Kingdom of Croatia and Kingdom of Hungary formed a personal union of two kingdoms united under the Hungarian king. The act of union was deal with Pacta conventa, by which institutions of separate Croatian statehood were maintained through the Sabor (an assembly of Croatian nobles) and the ban (viceroy). In addition, the Croatian nobles retained their lands and titles.

Medieval Hungary and Croatia were (in terms of public international law) allied by means of personal union until 1526. Although, Hungarian-Croatian state existed until the beginning of the 20th century and the Treaty of Trianon.

Henry I of England defeats his older brother Robert Curthose, duke of Normandy, at the Battle of Tinchebrai, and imprisons him in Devizes castle; Edgar Atheling and William Clito are also taken prisoner.
This victory made a later struggle between England and the rising Capetian power in France inevitable.
Through the Compromise of 1107, suggested by Adela, the sister of King Henry, the Investiture Struggle in England is ended.
This compromise removed one of the points of friction between the English monarchy and the Catholic Church.
In the Battle of Naklo, Boleslaus III Wrymouth defeats the Pomeranians.
Polish access to the sea is re-established.
In the Battle of Hundsfeld, Boleslaus III Wrymouth defeats Emperor Henry V.
German expansion to the centre of Europe is stopped.
The Byzantine army defeats the Turks at Philomelion.
The Turks abandon the entire coastal area of Anatolia and all of western Anatolia
The University of Oxford is founded.
It is the oldest university in the United Kingdom.
The Knights Templar are founded to protect Jerusalem and European pilgrims on their journey to the city.
Becomes the most recognizable, and impactful military orders during the Crusades.
St. Norbert and 29 companions make their solemn vows marking the beginning of the Premonstratensian Order.
This order played a significant role in evangelizing the Slavs, the Wends, to the east of the Holy Roman Empire.
The Concordat of Worms was drawn up between Emperor Henry V and Pope Calixtus II.
This concordat ended the investiture struggle, but bitter rivalry between emperor and pope remained.
The First Lateran Council followed and confirmed the Concordat of Worms.
Lothair of Supplinburg, duke of Saxony, is elected Holy Roman Emperor instead of the nearest heir, Frederick of Swabia.
This election marks the beginning of the great struggle between the Guelfs and the Ghibellines.
Jingkang Incident
The Jurchen soldiers sack Kaifeng, bringing an end to the Northern Song Dynasty in China; the Song moves further south and makes Lin'an their new capital.
Roger II is crowned King of Sicily, a royal title given him by the Antipope Anacletus II.

This coronation marks the beginning of the Kingdom of Sicily and its Mediterranean empire under the Norman kings, which was able to take on the Holy Roman Empire, the Papacy, and the Byzantine Empire.
The Anarchy begins in England.

This will mark a 19-year period of Government strife and Civil War between the supporters of Stephen and Matilda, and end with the crowning of Matilda's son, Henry II, and beginning the Plantagenet dynasty.
The Second Lateran Council declared clerical marriages invalid, regulated clerical dress, and punished attacks on clerics by excommunication.
April
Enforces the major reforms that Gregory VII began to heavily campaign for several decades earlier.
The Second Crusade was in retaliation for the fall of Edessa, one of the first Crusader States founded in the First Crusade. It was an overall failure.
This was the first Crusade to have been led by European kings.
Ramon Berenguer IV, Count of Barcelona, married Queen Petronilla of Aragon. They had been betrothed in 1137.
This marriage gave the Kingdom of Aragon access to the Mediterranean Sea, creating a powerful kingdom which expanded to control many of the Mediterranean lands.
The Synod of Kells-Mellifont established the present diocesan system of Ireland (with later modifications) and recognized the primacy of Armagh.
This synod marks the inclusion of the Irish Church into mainstream European Catholicism.
The Hanseatic League is founded.
This marks a new period of trade and economic development for northern and central Europe.
The first cornerstone is laid for the construction of Notre Dame de Paris.
Stefan Nemanja united Serbian territories, establishing the Medieval Serbian state.
This marks the rise of Serbia which will dominate the Balkans for the next three hundred years. Allies of Serbia at this moment become the Hungarian Kingdom and the Republic of Venice.
King Henry II of England lands in Ireland to assert his supremacy and the Synod of Cashel acknowledges his sovereignty.
With his landing, Henry begins the English claim to and occupation of Ireland which would last some seven and a half centuries.
King William I of Scotland, captured in the Battle of Alnwick by the English, accepts the feudal lordship of the English crown and does ceremonial allegiance at York.
This is the beginning of the gradual acquisition of Scotland by the English.
Hōnen Shōnin (Genkū) founds the Jōdo shū (Pure Land) sect of Buddhism.
This event marks the beginning of the Buddhist sectarian movement in Japan.
At the Battle of Legnano, the cavalry of Frederick Barbarossa is defeated by the infantry of the Lombard League.
This is the first major defeat of cavalry by infantry, signaling the new role of the bourgeoisie.
The Third Lateran Council limits papal electees to the cardinals alone, condemns simony, and forbids the promotion of anyone to the episcopate before the age of thirty.
March
The final Peace of Constance between Frederick Barbarossa, the pope, and the Lombard towns is signed.
The various articles of the treaty destroyed the unity of the Empire and Germany and Italy underwent separate developments.
The Taira clan are driven out of Kyōto by Minamoto Yoshinaka.
The two-year conflict which follows ends at the Battle of Dan no Ura (1185).
Pope Lucius III issues the papal bull Ad Abolendam.
November
This bull set up the organization of the medieval inquisitions.
Windmills are first recorded.
The reestablishment of the Bulgarian Empire.
At the Battle of Dan no Ura, Minamoto Yoshitsune annihilates the Taira clan.
The elimination of the Taira leaves the Minamoto the virtual rulers of Japan and marks the beginning of the first period of feudal rule known as the Kamakura Period.
The future emperor Henry VI marries Constance of Sicily, heiress to the Sicilian throne.
This marriage shifts the focus of the Guelphs/Ghibelline struggle to Sicily and marks the ruin of the House of Hohenstaufen.
Saladin recaptures Jerusalem.
Would lead to the Third Crusades.
Richard I ascends the throne of England.
July 6
His heavy taxation to finance his European ventures created an antipathy of barons and people toward the crown, but his being absent enabled the English to advance in their political development.
The Third Crusade follows upon Saladin's uniting the Muslim world and recapturing Jerusalem.
Despite managing to win several major battles, the Crusaders did not recapture Jerusalem.
Minamoto Yoritomo is appointed Sei-i Taishōgun, or shōgun for short.
He is the first of a long line of military dictators to bear this title. The institution would last until 1913.
Turkic Muslim invaders sack and burn the university at Nalanda.
This is the beginning of the decline of Buddhism in India.
The first known merchant guild.
Europeans first use compasses.
Europeans first use compasses.

The Fourth Crusade sacked Croatian town of Zadar (Italian: Zara), a rival of Venice. Unable to raise enough funds to pay to their Venetian contractors, the crusaders agreed to sack the city despite letters from Pope Innocent III forbidding such an action and threatening excommunication.
Siege of Zara was the first major Crusade's action and the first attack against a Catholic city by Catholic crusaders.
Sack of Constantinople during the Fourth Crusade.
Considered to be the beginning of the decline of the Byzantine Empire.
Battle of Adrianople. The Bulgarians under Emperor Kaloyan defeat Baldwin I.
Beginning of the decline of the Latin Empire.
Genghis Khan was elected as Khagan of the Mongols and the Mongol Empire was established.
The Mongols would conquer much of Eurasia, changing former political borders.
Pope Innocent III calls for the Albigensian Crusade which seeks to destroy a rival form of Christianity practiced by the Cathars.
Pope Innocent III calls for the Albigensian Crusade which seeks to destroy a rival form of Christianity practiced by the Cathars.
The University of Cambridge is founded.
Founding of the Franciscan Order.
One of the more significant orders in the Roman Catholic church, founded by Saint Francis of Assisi.
Spanish Christians succeed in defeating the Moors in the long Reconquista campaigns, after the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa.
By 1248, only the small southern kingdom of Granada remained under Muslim control.
The Magna Carta is sealed by John of England.
15 June
This marks one of the first times a medieval ruler is forced to accept limits on his power.
Fourth Lateran Council. Dealt with transubstantiation, papal primacy and conduct of clergy. Proclaimed that Jews and Muslims should wear identification marks to distinguish them from Christians.
Papal recognition of the Dominican Order.
Serbian Orthodox Church becomes autocephalous under St. Sava, its first Archbishop.
Serbian Orthodox Church becomes autocephalous under St. Sava, its first Archbishop.
Genghis Khan dies.
18 August

His kingdom is divided among his children and grandchildren: Empire of the Great Khan, Chagatai Khanate, Mongolian Homeland, and the Blue Horde and White Horde. (Which would later become the Golden Horde.
Mongol invasion of Rus' resumes.
Causes the split of Kievan Rus' into three components (present day Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, greatly effects various regions of raided lands in other parts of Europe; Golden Horde formed.
Founding of the University of Paris.
Provisions of Oxford forced upon Henry III of England.
This establishes a new form of government-limited regal authority.
Siege of Baghdad
29 January– 10 February
Mongols (the Ilkhanate) ensure control of the region; Generally considered the end of the Islamic Golden Age.
The Ninth Crusade occurs.
Considered to be the Last Major Crusade to take place in the Holy Land.
Rudolph I of Germany is elected Holy Roman Emperor.
29 September
This begins the Habsburg de facto domination of the crown that lasted until is dissolution in 1806.
Thomas Aquinas' work, Summa Theologica is published, after his death.
Is the main staple of theology during the Middle Ages.
Battle of Yamen.
19 March
Marks the end of the Song Dynasty in China, and all of China is under the rule of Kublai Khan as the emperor.
Sicilian Vespers. Sicilians massacre Angevins over a six-week period, after a Frenchman harassed a woman.
Would mark a two decade period of war, and peace treaties mainly between Aragon, Sicily, and the Angevins.
Catalan Courts.
Presided by king Peter III of Aragon for the whole Principality of Catalonia, it became in one of the first medieval parliaments that banned the royal power to create legislation unilaterally.
Edward I of England invades Scotland, starting the First War of Scottish Independence.
The Battle of Stirling Bridge.
11 September
William Wallace emerges as the leader of the Scottish resistance to England.
Marco Polo publishes his tales of China, along with Rustichello da Pisa.
A key step to the bridging of Asia and Europe in trade.
The Ottoman Empire is founded by Osman I.
27 July
Becomes longest lasting Islamic Empire, lasting over 600 years into the 20th century...
William Wallace is executed for treason.
August 23
William Wallace is executed for treason.
The Knights Templar are rounded up and murdered by Philip the Fair of France, with the backing of the Pope.
Friday, October 13th
Hastens the demise of the order within a decade.
Beginning of the Babylonian Captivity of the Papacy during which the Popes moved to Avignon.
Begins a period of over seven decades of the Papacy outside of Rome that would be one of the major factors of the Western Schism.
Dante publishes his Divine Comedy.
Is one of the most defining works of literature during the Late Middle Ages, and among the most recognizable in all of literature.
Battle of Bannockburn.
23–24 June
Robert the Bruce restores Scotland's de facto independence.
The Aztecs found the city of Tenochtitlan.
This would be the epicenter and capital of the Aztec kingdom for nearly 200 years until the Siege of Tenochtitlan led by Hernán Cortés.
The First War of Scottish Independence ends in Scottish victory with the Treaty of Edinburgh-Northampton and de jure independence.
Emperor Go-Daigo returns to the throne from exile, and begins the Kenmu restoration.
The Kamakura Shogunate comes to an end, and the Kenmu Restoration only lasts a few years before the Ashikaga Shogunate begins.
The Hundred Years' War begins. England and France struggle for a dominating position in Europe and their region.
The war will span through three/four different war periods within a 116-year period.
Battle of Crécy.
August 26th

English forces led by Edward III and Edward, the Black Prince defeat the French forces of Philip VI despite being outnumbered at least 4 to 1, with the longbow being a major factor in favor of England. Also considered to be the beginning of the end of classic chivalry.
The Black Death ravages Europe for the first of many times. An estimated 20% - 40% of the population is thought to have perished within the first year.
The first of many concurrences of this plague, This was believed to have wiped out as many as 50% of Europe's population by its end.
The University of Prague is founded.
It is the oldest Czech and German-Speaking University in the world
The fall of the Yuan Dynasty. Its remnants, known as Northern Yuan, continued to rule Mongolia.
The breakup of the Mongol Empire, which marked the end of Pax Mongolica.
Tamerlane establishes the Timurid Dynasty.
During this 35-year period, Tamerlane would ravage his fellow Islamic states such as the Golden Horde and the Delhi Sultanate in order to accomplish his goal of a restored Mongol Empire.
The Western Schism during which three claimant popes were elected simultaneously.
The Avignon Papacy ends.
Prince Dmitry Donskoy of Moscow led a united Russian army to a victory over the Mongols in the Battle of Kulikovo.
Chaucer begins to write The Canterbury Tales.
Chaucer's greatest work, and one of the foundations towards the formation of the Modern English language
Peasants' Revolt in England.
Quickest-spread revolt in English history, and the most popular revolt of the Late Middle Ages.
The Bible is translated into English by John Wycliffe.
First print published in English (Vulgate)
The University of Heidelberg is founded.
October 18-19th
It is the oldest university in Germany.
Battle of Kosovo in Serbia.
June 28th

This was in many respects the decisive battle between the Turks, led by Sultan Murat, and Christian army, led by the Serbs and their duke Lazar. The battle took place in Kosovo, the southern province of the Medieval Serbian Empire. After this battle Turkish empire continued to spread over the Balkans, to finally reach Vienna.
Joseon Dynasty founded in Korea.
Becomes longest reigning Korean dynasty.
The Battle of Nicopolis.
The last great Crusade fails.
The Kalmar Union is formed.
Queen Margaret I of Denmark unites the Denmark, Sweden, and Norway, and lasts until 1523.
Richard II abdicates the throne to Henry of Bolingbroke, who becomes Henry IV of England.
End of Plantagenet Dynasty, beginning of the Lancaster lineage of kings.
Battle of Ankara
July 20th
Bayezid I is captured by Tamerlane's forces, causing the interregnum of the Ottoman Empire.
Chinese Naval Expeditions of Southeast Asia and the Indian Ocean (to Eastern Africa) begins, under the leadership of Zheng He.
This will be the first of seven of the Ming Dynasty-sponsored expeditions, lasting until 1433.
Ladislaus of Naples sells his "rights" on Dalmatia to the Venetian Republic for 100,000 ducats.
Dalmatia would with some interruptions remain under Venetian rule for nearly four centuries, until 1797.
Kingdom of Portugal conquers Ceuta.
Beginning of the Portuguese Empire.
Battle of Agincourt. Henry V and his army defeat a numerically superior French army, partially because of the newly introduced English longbow.
October 25th
The turning point in the Hundred Years' War for 15th Century England that lead to the signing of the Treaty of Troyes signed 5 years later, making Henry V heir of France.
The Council of Constance ends.
The Western Schism comes to a close, and elects Pope Martin V as the sole pope.
Hussite Wars begins after 4 years after the death of Jan Hus in central Europe, dealing with the followers of Jan Hus and those against them.
Although the war was a stalemate (ended around 1434), it was another factor that[clarification needed] between the Catholics and Protestants before the Protestant Reformation.
Joan of Arc lifts the siege of Orléans for the Dauphin of France, enabling him to eventually be crowned at Reims.
The battle at Orléans is the first of many which ultimately drive the English from continental Europe.
Trial and execution of Joan of Arc.
30 May
Death of the woman who helped turned the Hundred Years' War in favor of the French over the past two years.
The Medici family rises to prominence in Florence.

This ushers in a period of significance of the Medici's, such as bankers, popes, queens (regents) and dukes, throughout Europe (mainly Italy, especially the Florentine Republic), over the next three centuries.
Johannes Gutenberg invents the printing press.
Literature, News, etc. becomes more accessible throughout Europe.
Battle of Szeben
Third significant victory for the Hungarian forces led by Janos Hunyadi over the Ottoman forces.
Battle of Varna
November 10th
Final battle of the Crusade of Varna; Ottomans are victorious over the Hungarian-Polish armies, and Władysław III of Poland dies.
Constantinople falls to the Ottoman Turks.
End of the Byzantine Empire (or Eastern Roman Empire to some); Constantinople becomes capital of Ottoman Empire.
The Hundred Years' War ends.
England's once vast territories in France is now reduced to only Calais, which they eventually lose control of as well.
Battle of St. Albans
May 22
Traditionally marks the beginning of the War of the Roses.
Siege of Belgrade
Major Ottoman advances are halted for 7 decades, last major victory for Hunyadi.
Smederevo falls under the Turks
Marks the end of the Medieval Serbian Empire.
The Empire of Trebizond falls to the Ottoman Turks.
Last Roman outpost to be conquered by the Ottomans.
Ōnin War takes place in Japan.
First of many significant civil wars between shogunates that would continue for another century during the Muromachi period.
Thomas Malory composes Le Morte d'Arthur
Perhaps the best-known work of Arthurian literature in English.
Battle of Bosworth Field.
August 22nd
Richard III dies in battle, and Henry Tudor becomes king of England; last shift of Houses/kingship during the War of the Roses.
Battle of Stoke.
June 16
Marks end of the War of the Roses.
Reconquista ends.
Marks end of Moorish/Muslim rule within Iberian Peninsula; Unification of Spain and Portugal, respectively.
Christopher Columbus reaches the New World.
Age of Discovery into the New World begins.
Spain and Portugal sign the Treaty of Tordesillas and agree to divide the World outside of Europe between themselves.
June 10
Pope's ruling will lead to the division of Brazil and Spanish America, as well as the formation of the Spanish Philippines and Portuguese colonies in India and Africa.
The Italian Wars.
Italian Wars will eventually lead to the downfall of the Italian city-states.
Vasco da Gama begins his first voyage from Europe to India and back.
Vasco da Gama was the first European to sail directly to Eastern Asia from Europe.
Ottoman fleet defeats Venetians at the Battle of Zonchio.
The first naval battle that used cannons in ships.
Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Spain was born.
Guru Nanak the beginning and spreading of the 5th largest Religion in the World Sikhism.
Spanish navigator Vicente Yáñez Pinzón encounters Brazil but is prevented from claiming it by the Treaty of Tordesillas.
Portuguese navigator Pedro Álvares Cabral claims Brazil for Portugal.
The Ottoman fleet of Kemal Reis defeats the Venetians at the Second Battle of Lepanto.
Michelangelo returns to his native Florence to begin work on the statue David.
Safavid dynasty reunified Iran and ruled over it until 1736. Safavids adopt a Shia branch of Islam.
First reported African slaves in The New World
Foundation of the Sultanate of Sennar by Amara Dunqas, in what is modern Sudan
Spain defeats France at the Battle of Cerignola. Considered to be the first battle in history won by gunpowder small arms.
Leonardo da Vinci begins painting the Mona Lisa and completes it three years later.
Nostradamus was born on either December 14, or December 21.
A period of drought, with famine in all of Spain.
Death of Isabella I of Castile, Joanna of Castille became the Queen.
Zhengde Emperor ascended the throne of Ming Dynasty.

King Sultan Trenggono built the first Moslem kingdom in Java, called Demak, in Indonesia . Many other small kingdoms were established in other islands to fight against Portuguese. Each kingdom introduced local language as a way of communication and unity.
Leonardo da Vinci completes the Mona Lisa.
King Afonso I of Kongo wins the battle of Mbanza Kongo, resulting in Catholicism becoming Kongo's state religion.
At least two thousand converted Jews are massacred in a Lisbon riot, Portugal.
Christopher Columbus dies in Valladolid, Spain.
Poland is invaded by Tatars from the Crimean Khanate.
The first recorded epidemic of smallpox in the New World on the island of Hispaniola. It devastates the native Taíno population.
Afonso de Albuquerque conquered Hormuz and Muscat, among other bases in the Persian Gulf, taking control of the region at the entrance of the Gulf.
Michelangelo paints the Sistine Chapel ceiling.
The Battle of Diu marks the beginning of Portuguese dominance of the Spice trade and the Indian Ocean.

The Portuguese king sends Diogo Lopes de Sequeira to find Malacca, the eastern terminus of Asian trade. After initially receiving Sequeira, Sultan Mahmud Syah captures and/or kills several of his men and attempts an assault on the four Portuguese ships, which escape. The Javanese fleet is also destroyed in Malacca.
The 'great plague' in various parts of Tudor England.
Afonso de Albuquerque of Portugal conquers Malacca, the capital of the Sultanate of Malacca in present-day Malaysia.
Copernicus writes Commentariolus, and proclaims the sun the center of the solar system.
The southern part (historical core) of the Kingdom of Navarre is invaded by Castile and Aragon.

The first Portuguese exploratory expedition was sent eastward from Malacca (in present-day Malaysia) to search for the 'Spice Islands' (Maluku) led by Francisco Serrão. Serrao is shipwrecked but struggles on to Hitu (northern Ambon) and wins the favour of the local rulers.
Machiavelli writes The Prince, a treatise about political philosophy
The Portuguese mariner Jorge Álvares lands at Macau, China, during the Ming Dynasty.
Henry VIII defeats the French at the Battle of the Spurs.
The Battle of Flodden Field in which invading Scots are defeated by Henry VIII's forces.
Sultan Selim I ("The Grim") orders the massacre of Shia Muslims in Anatolia (present-day Turkey).
Vasco Núñez de Balboa, in service of Spain arrives at the Pacific Ocean (which he called Mar del Sur) across the Isthmus of Panama. He was the first European to do so.
The Battle of Orsha halts Muscovy's expansion into Eastern Europe.
Dózsa rebellion (peasant revolt) in Hungary.
The Battle of Chaldiran, the Ottoman Empire gains decisive victory against Safavid dynasty.
The Ottoman Empire wrests Eastern Anatolia from the Safavids after the Battle of Chaldiran.
The Ottomans defeat the Mamluks and gain control of Egypt, Arabia, and the Levant.
The Sweating sickness epidemic in Tudor England.
The Protestant Reformation begins when Martin Luther posts his 95 Theses in Saxony.
Mir Chakar Khan Rind leaves Baluchistan and settled in Punjab.

Leo Africanus, also known as al-Hasan ibn Muhammad al-Wazzan al-Fasi, Arabic:حسن ابن محمد الوزان الفاسي), an Andalusian Berber diplomat who is best known for his book Descrittione dell’Africa (Description of Africa) describing the geography of North Africa, is captured by Spanish pirates; he will be taken to Rome and presented to Pope Leo X.
The Dancing Plague of 1518 begins in Strasbourg, lasting for about one month.
Leonardo da Vinci dies of natural causes on May 2.

Wang Yangming, the Chinese philosopher and governor of Jiangxi province, describes his intent to use the firepower of the fo-lang-ji, a breech-loading Portuguese culverin, in order to suppress the rebellion of Prince Zhu Chen-hao.
Barbary pirates led by Hayreddin Barbarossa a Turk appointed to ruling position in Algiers by the Ottoman Empire, raid Provence and Toulon in southern France.
Charles I of Spain becomes Emperor of Holy Roman Empire as Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor (ruled until 1556).
Spanish expedition commanded by Magellan and Elcano first to circle Earth
Hernán Cortés leads the Spanish conquest of Mexico.
The reign of Suleiman the Magnificent marks the zenith of the Ottoman Empire.
The first European diplomatic mission to Ethiopia, sent by the Portuguese, arrives at Massawa 9 April, and reaches the imperial encampment of Emperor Dawit II in Shewa 9 October.
The Yousafzais defeat Dilazaks at the battle of Katlang to found the Yousafzai dynasty in Pakhtunkhwa in modern-day Pakistan and Afghanistan.
The Portuguese established a trading post in the village of Lamakera on the eastern side of Solor (in present-day Indonesia) as a transit harbour between Maluku and Malacca.
Sultan Ali Mughayat Shah of Aceh begins an expansionist campaign capturing Daya on the west Sumatran coast (in present-day Indonesia), and the pepper and gold producing lands on the east coast.
Belgrade (in present-day Serbia) is captured by the Ottoman Empire.
After building fortifications at Tuen Mun, the Portuguese attempt to invade Ming Dynasty China, but are expelled by Chinese naval forces.
Philippines encountered by Ferdinand Magellan. He was later killed in battle in central Philippines in the same year.
Jiajing Emperor ascended the throne of Ming Dynasty, China.
November, Ferdinand Magellan's expedition reaches Maluku (in present-day Indonesia) and after trade with Ternate returns to Europe with a load of cloves.
Pati Unus led invasion of Malacca (in present-day Malaysia) against the Portuguese occupation. Pati Unus was killed in this battle, and was succeeded by his brother, king Trenggana.
Rhodes falls to the Ottoman Turks of Suleiman the Magnificent.
The Portuguese ally themselves with the rulers of Ternate (in present-day Indonesia) and begin construction of a fort.
August, Luso Sundanese Treaty signed between Portugal and Sunda Kingdom granted Portuguese permit to build fortress in Sunda Kelapa
Sweden gains independence from the Kalmar Union.
The cacao bean was introduced to Spain by Hernán Cortés
German Peasants' War in the Holy Roman Empire.
1524 – Giovanni da Verrazzano is the first European to explore the Atlantic coast of North America between South Carolina and Newfoundland.
1524 - Ismail I, the founder of Safavid dynasty, dies and Tahmasp I becomes king.
Spain and Germany defeat France at the Battle of Pavia, Francis I of France is captured.
The Ottomans defeat the Kingdom of Hungary at the Battle of Mohács.
Mughal Empire, founded by Babur, rules India until 1857.
Sack of Rome, which is considered the end of the Italian Renaissance.
Protestant Reformation begins in Sweden.

The last ruler of Majapahit falls from power. This state (located in present-day Indonesia) was finally extinguished at the hands of the Demak. A large number of courtiers, artisans, priests, and members of the royalty moved east to the island of Bali; however, the power and the seat of government transferred to Demak under the leadership of Pangeran, later Sultan Fatah.

June 22, The Javanese Prince Fatahillah of the Cirebon Sultanate successfully defeated the Portuguese armed forces at the site of the Sunda Kelapa Harbor. The city was then renamed Jayakarta, meaning "a glorious victory." This eventful day came to be acknowledged as Jakarta's Founding Anniversary, and Fatahillah Park was named after the heroic prince.
The Austrians defeat the Ottoman Empire at the Siege of Vienna.
Treaty of Zaragoza defined the antimeridian of Tordesillas attributing the Moluccas to Portugal and Philippines to Spain.
Imam Ahmad Gragn defeats the Ethiopian Emperor Dawit II in the Battle of Shimbra Kure, the opening clash of the Ethiopian–Adal War
The Church of England breaks away from the Roman Catholic Church and recognizes King Henry VIII as the head of the Church.
The Inca Civil War is fought between the two brothers, Atahualpa and Huáscar.
Francisco Pizarro leads the Spanish conquest of the Inca Empire.
Anne Boleyn becomes Queen of England.
Elizabeth Tudor is born.
Jacques Cartier claims Quebec for France.
The Ottomans capture Baghdad.
Affair of the Placards – Francis becomes more active in repression of French Protestants.
The Münster Rebellion, an attempt of radical, millennialist, Anabaptists to establish a theocracy ends in bloodshed.

The Portuguese in Ternate depose Sultan Tabariji (or Tabarija) and send him to Portuguese Goa where he converts to Christianity and bequeaths his Portuguese godfather Jordao de Freitas the island of Ambon.
Katherine of Aragon dies in Kimbolton Castle, in England.
In England, Anne Boleyn is beheaded for adultery and treason.
Establishment of the Inquisition in Portugal
Foundation of Buenos Aires (in present-day Argentina) by Pedro de Mendoza
Portuguese establishes Recife in Pernambuco, north-east of Brazil.
William Tyndale's partial translation of the Bible into English is published, which would eventually be incorporated into the King James Bible.
Gonzalo Jiménez de Quesada founds Bogotá.
Spanish–Venetian fleet is defeated by the Ottoman Turks at the Battle of Preveza.
Hernando de Soto explores inland North America.

Sher Shah Suri founds Suri dynasty in South Asia, an ethnic Pashtun (Pathan) of the house of Sur, who supplanted the Mughal dynasty as rulers of North India during the reign of the relatively ineffectual second Mughal emperor Humayun. Sher Shah decisively defeats Central Asian invader Humayun in the Battle of Bilgram (May 17, 1540).
Pedro de Valdivia founds Santiago de Chile.
An Algerian military campaign by Charles V of Spain (Habsburg) is unsuccessful.
Amazon River is encountered and explored by Francisco de Orellana.
Capture of Buda and the absorption of the major part of Hungary by the Ottoman Empire.
Sahib I Giray of Crimea invades Russia.
War resumes between Francis I of France and Emperor Charles V. This time Henry VIII is allied with the Emperor, while James V of Scotland and Sultan Suleiman I are allied with the French.
Spanish explorer Ruy López de Villalobos named the island of Samar and Leyte Las Islas Filipinas honoring Philip II of Spain and became the official name of the archipelago.
Ethiopian/Portuguese troops decisively defeat the Adal-Ottoman Muslim army at the Battle of Wayna Daga; Imam Ahmad Gragn killed.
Copernicus publishes his theory that the Earth and the other planets revolve around the Sun
The Nanban trade period begins after Portuguese traders make contact with Japan.
The French defeat an Imperial–Spanish army at the Battle of Ceresole.
Battle of the Shirts in Scotland. The Frasers and Macdonalds of Clan Ranald fight over a disputed chiefship; reportedly, 5 Frasers and 8 Macdonalds survive.
Songhai forces sack the Malian capital of Niani
The Council of Trent meets for the first time in Trent (in northern Italy).
Michelangelo Buonarroti is made chief architect of St. Peter's Basilica.
Francis Xavier works among the peoples of Ambon, Ternate and Morotai (Moro) laying the foundations for a permanent mission. (to 1547)
Henry VIII dies in the Palace of Whitehall on 28 January at the age of 55.
Edward VI becomes King of England and Ireland on 28 January and is crowned on 20 February at the age of 9.
Emperor Charles V decisively dismantles the Schmalkaldic League at the Battle of Mühlberg.
Grand Prince Ivan the Terrible is crowned tsar of (All)Russia, thenceforth becoming the first Russian tsar.
Battle of Uedahara
Firearms are used for the first time on the battlefield in Japan, and Takeda Shingen is defeated by Murakami Yoshikiyo.
Askia Daoud, who reigned from 1548 to 1583, establishes public libraries in Timbuktu (in present-day Mali).
The Ming Dynasty government of China issues a decree banning all foreign trade and closes down all seaports along the coast; these Hai jin laws came during the Wokou wars with Japanese pirates.
Tomé de Souza establishes Salvador in Bahia, north-east of Brazil.

Arya Penangsang with the support of his teacher, Sunan Kudus, avenged the death of Raden Kikin by sending an envoy named Rangkud to kill Sunan Prawoto by Keris Kyai Satan Kober (in present-day Indonesia).
The architect Mimar Sinan builds the Süleymaniye Mosque in Istanbul.
Mongols led by Altan Khan invade China and besiege Beijing.
Valladolid debate concerning the human rights of the Indigenous people of the Americas
Fifth outbreak of sweating sickness in England. John Caius of Shrewsbury writes the first full contemporary account of the symptoms of the disease.
North African pirates enslave the entire population of the Maltese island Gozo, between 5,000 and 6,000, sending them to Libya.
Russia conquers the Khanate of Kazan in central Asia.
Mary Tudor becomes the first queen regnant of England and restores the Church of England under Papal authority.
Portuguese found a settlement at Macau.
Portuguese missionaries José de Anchieta and Manuel da Nóbrega establishes São Paulo, southeast Brazil.
Princess Elizabeth is imprisoned in the Tower of London upon the orders of Mary I for suspicion of being involved in the Wyatt rebellion.
The Muscovy Company is the first major English joint stock trading company.
Publication in Venice of Delle Navigiationi et Viaggi (terzo volume) by Giovanni Battista Ramusio, secretary of Council of Ten, with plan La Terra de Hochelaga, an illustration of the Hochelaga.
The Shaanxi earthquake in China is history's deadliest known earthquake during the Ming dynasty.
Georgius Agricola, the "Father of Mineralogy", publishes his De re metallica.
Akbar the Great defeats the Sultan of Bengal at the Second battle of Panipat
Russia conquers the Astrakhan Khanate.
During his reign, Akbar expands the Mughal Empire in a series of conquests (in the Indian subcontinent).
Mir Chakar Khan Rind captured Delhi with Emperor Humayun.
Pomponio Algerio, radical theologian, is executed by boiling in oil as part of the Roman inquisition.
Habsburg Spain declares bankruptcy. Philip II of Spain had to declare four state bankruptcies in 1557, 1560, 1575 and 1596.
The Portuguese settle in Macau (on the western side of the Pearl River Delta across from present-day Hong Kong).
The Ottomans capture Massawa, all but isolating Ethiopia from the rest of the world.
Elizabeth Tudor becomes Queen Elizabeth I at age 25.
The Elizabethan era is considered the height of the English Renaissance.
Livonian War between Poland, Grand Principality of Lithuania, Sweden, Denmark and Russia.
After 200 years, the Kingdom of England loses Calais to France.
With the Peace of Cateau Cambrésis, the Italian Wars conclude.
Sultan Khairun of Ternate (in present-day Indonesia) protests the Portuguese's Christianisation activities in his lands. Hostilities between Ternate and the Portuguese.
Ottoman navy defeats the Spanish fleet at the Battle of Djerba.
Elizabeth Bathory is born in Nyirbator, Hungary.
By winning the Battle of Okehazama, Oda Nobunaga becomes one of the pre-eminent warlords of Japan
Sir Francis Bacon is born in London.
Guido de Bres draws up the Belgic Confession of Protestant faith.
Mughal leader Akbar reconciles the Muslim and Hindu factions by marrying into the powerful Rajput Hindu caste.
French Wars of Religion between Catholics and Huguenots.
Massacre of Wassy and Battle of Dreux in the French Wars of Religion.

Portuguese Dominican priests build a palm-trunk fortress which Javanese Muslims burned down the following year. The fort was rebuilt from more durable materials and the Dominicans commenced the Christianisation of the local population.
Plague outbreak claimed 80,000 people in Elizabethan England. In London alone, over 20,000 people died of the disease.
Galileo Galilei born on February 15
William Shakespeare baptized 26 April
Battle of Talikota fought between the Hindu kingdom of Vijayanagar and the Deccan sultanates.
Mir Chakar Khan Rind died age of 97.
Estácio de Sá establishes Rio de Janeiro in Brazil.
The Hospitallers, a Crusading Order, defeat the Ottoman Empire at the Siege of Malta (1565).
Miguel López de Legazpi establishes in Cebu the first Spanish settlement in the Philippines starting a period of Spanish colonization that would last over three hundred years.
Spanish navigator Andres de Urdaneta discovers the maritime route from Asia to the Americas across the Pacific Ocean, also known as the tornaviaje.
Suleiman the Magnificent, ruler of the Ottoman Empire, dies on September 7.
Eighty Years' War between Spain and the Netherlands.
After 45 years' reign, Jiajing Emperor died in the Forbidden City, Longqing Emperor ascended the throne of Ming Dynasty.
Mary, Queen of Scots, is imprisoned by Elizabeth I.

The Transylvanian Diet, under the patronage of the prince John Sigismund Zápolya, the former King of Hungary, inspired by the teachings of Ferenc Dávid, the founder of the Unitarian Church of Transylvania, promulgates the Edict of Torda, the first law of Freedom of religion and of conscience in the World.
Morisco Revolt in Spain.
The Azuchi-Momoyama period in Japan.
Hadiwijaya sent his adopted son and son in-law Sutawijaya, who would later become the first ruler of the Mataram dynasty of Indonesia, to kill Aryo Penangsang.
Rising of the North in England.
The Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth is created with the Union of Lublin which lasts until 1795.
Peace treaty signed by Sultan Khairun of Ternate and Governor Lopez De Mesquita of Portuguese.
Ivan the Terrible, tsar of Russia, orders the massacre of inhabitants of Novgorod.
Pope Pius V issues Regnans in Excelsis, a papal bull excommunicating all who obeyed Elizabeth I and calling on all Roman Catholics to rebel against her.
Sultan Hairun of Ternate (in present-day Indonesia) is killed by the Portuguese. The reign of Sultan Baabullah.
Pope Pius V completes the Holy League as a united front against the Ottoman Turks.
The Spanish-led Holy League navy destroys the Ottoman Empire navy at the Battle of Lepanto.
Crimean Tatars attack and sack Moscow, burning everything but the Kremlin.
American Indians kill Spanish missionaries in what would later be Jamestown, Virginia.
Spanish conquistador Miguel López de Legazpi establishes Manila, Philippines as the capital of the Spanish East Indies.
Brielle is taken from Habsburg Spain by Protestant Watergeuzen in the Capture of Brielle, in the Eighty Years' War.
Spanish conquistadores apprehend the last Inca leader Tupak Amaru at Vilcabamba, Peru, and execute him in Cuzco.

Catherine de' Medici instigates the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre which takes the lives of Protestant leader Gaspard de Coligny and thousands of Huguenots. The violence spreads from Paris to other cities and the countryside.
First edition of the epic The Lusiads of Luís Vaz de Camões, three years after the author returned from the East.
The 9 years old Taizi, Zhu Yijun ascended the throne of Ming Dynasty, known as Wanli Emperor.
After heavy losses on both sides the Siege of Haarlem ends in a Spanish victory.
in the Eighty Years' War the capital of Zeeland, Middelburg declares for the Protestants.
After a siege of 4 months the Siege of Leiden ends in a comprehensive Dutch rebel victory.
Oda Nobunaga finally captures Nagashima fortress.
Following a five-year war, the Ternateans under Sultan Baabullah defeated the Portuguese.
Tahmasp I, Safavid king, died.
Sack of Antwerp by badly paid Spanish soldiers.
Francis Drake circles the world.
Ki Ageng Pemanahan built his palace in Pasargede or Kotagede.
King Sebastian of Portugal is killed at the Battle of Alcazarquivir.
The Portuguese establish a fort on Tidore but the main centre for Portuguese activities in Maluku becomes Ambon.
The Union of Utrecht unifies the northern Netherlands, a foundation for the later Dutch Republic.
The Union of Arras unifies the southern Netherlands, a foundation for the later states of the Spanish Netherlands, the Austrian Netherlands and Belgium

The British navigator Sir Francis Drake passes through Maluku and transit in Ternate on his circumnavigation of the world. The Portuguese establish a fort on Tidore but the main centre for Portuguese activities in Maluku becomes Ambon.
Drake's royal reception after his attacks on Spanish possessions influences Philip II of Spain to build up the Spanish Armada. English ships in Spanish harbours are impounded.
Spain unifies with Portugal under Philip II. The struggle for the throne of Portugal ends the Portuguese Empire. The Spanish and Portuguese crowns are united for 60 years, i.e. until 1640.
Oda Nobunaga is assassinated by his general, Akechi Mitsuhide.

Pope Gregory XIII issues the Gregorian calendar. The last day of the Julian calendar was Thursday, 4 October 1582 and this was followed by the first day of the Gregorian calendar, Friday, 15 October 1582
Yermak Timofeyevich conquers the Siberia Khanate on behalf of the Stroganovs.
Death of Sultan Baabullah of Ternate.

After the Siege of Antwerp, many of its merchants flee to Amsterdam. According to Luc-Normand Tellier, "At its peak, between 1510 and 1557, Antwerp concentrated about 40% of the world trade...It is estimated that the port of Antwerp was earning the Spanish crown seven times more revenues than the Americas."
Ki Ageng Pemanahan died. Sultan Pajang raised Sutawijaya, son of Ki Ageng Pemanahan as the new ruler in Mataram, titled "Loring Ngabehi Market" (because his home in the north of the market).
Colony at Roanoke founded in North America
The Anglo-Spanish War is fought on both sides of the Atlantic.
The reign of Abbas I marks the zenith of the Safavid dynasty.
troops that would invade Pajang Sultanate of Mataram storm ravaged the eruption of Mount Merapi. Sutawijaya and his men survived.
Mataram into the kingdom with Sutawijaya as Sultan, titled "Senapati Ingalaga Sayidin Panatagama" means the warlord and cleric Manager Religious Life.
England repulses the Spanish Armada.
Spain repulses the English Armada.
Siege of Odawara the Go-Hojo clan surrendered to Toyotomi Hideyoshi, and Japan was unified (1590).
Gazi Giray leads a huge Tatar expedition against Moscow.
In Mali, Moroccan forces of the Sultan Ahmad al-Mansur led by Judar Pasha defeat the Songhai Empire at the Battle of Tondibi.
John Stow reports 10,675 plague deaths in London, a city of approximately 200,000 people.
Korea, with the help of Ming Dynasty China, repels two Japanese invasions.
The Long War between the Habsburg monarchy and the Ottoman Turks.
First Dutch expedition to Indonesia sets sail for the East Indies with two hundred and forty-nine men and sixty-four cannons led by Cornelis de Houtman.
Birth of René Descartes.

June, de Houtman’s expedition reaches Banten the main pepper port of West Java where they clash with both the Portuguese and Indonesians. It then sails east along the north coast of Java losing twelve crew to a Javanese attack at Sidayu and killing a local ruler in Madura.
de Houtman’s expedition returns to the Netherlands with enough spices to make a considerable profit.
The Edict of Nantes ends the French Wars of Religion.
Abbas I moved Safavids capital from Qazvin to Isfahan in 1598.
Russia descends into anarchy during the Time of Troubles.
The Portuguese require an armada of 90 ships to put down a Solorese uprising. (to 1599)
More Dutch fleets leave for Indonesia and most are profitable.
The Mali Empire is defeated at the Battle of Jenné
The van Neck expedition returns to Europe. The expedition makes a 400 per cent profit. (to 1600)
March, Leaving Europe the previous year, a fleet of eight ships under Jacob van Neck was the first Dutch fleet to reach the ‘Spice Islands’ of Maluku.
Giordano Bruno is burned at the stake for heresy in Rome.
Battle of Sekigahara in Japan. End of the Warring States period and beginning of the Edo period.

The Portuguese win a major naval battle in the bay of Ambon. Later in the year, the Dutch join forces with the local Hituese in an anti-Portuguese alliance, in return for which the Dutch would have the sole right to purchase spices from Hitu.
Elizabeth I grants a charter to the British East India Company beginning the English advance in Asia.
On February 17 Giordano Bruno is burned at the stake by the Inquisition.
Michael the Brave unifies the three Romanian countries: Wallachia, Moldavia and Transylvania after the Battle of Șelimbăr from 1599.
Battle of Kinsale, England defeats Irish and Spanish forces at the town of Kinsale, driving the Gaelic aristocracy out of Ireland and destroying the Gaelic clan system.
Michael the Brave (first unifier of Romania), voivode of Wallachia, Moldavia and Transylvania, is assassinated by the order of the Habsburg general Giorgio Basta at Câmpia Turzii.
The Russian famine of 1601–1603 kills perhaps one-third of Russia.
Panembahan Senopati, first king of Mataram, dies and passes rule to his son Panembahan Seda ing Krapyak
Matteo Ricci is given permission to live in Beijing.
Matteo Ricci produces the Map of the Myriad Countries of the World (坤輿萬國全圖, Kūnyú Wànguó Quántú), a world map that will be used throughout East Asia for centuries.
The Portuguese send a major (and last) expeditionary force from Malacca which succeeded in reimposing a degree of Portuguese control.
The Dutch East India Company (VOC) is established by merging competing Dutch trading companies. Its success contributes to the Dutch Golden Age.

June, British East India Company's first voyage, commanded by Sir James Lancaster, arrives in Aceh and sails on to Bantam where he is allowed to build trading post which becomes the centre of British trade in Indonesia until 1682.
Two emissaries from the Aceh Sultanate visit the Dutch Republic.
Elizabeth I of England dies and is succeeded by her cousin King James VI of Scotland, uniting the crowns of Scotland and England.
Tokugawa Ieyasu takes the title of Shogun, establishing the Tokugawa Shogunate. This begins the Edo period, which will last until 1869.
After modernizing his army, Abbas I expands the Persian Empire by capturing territory from the Ottomans and the Portuguese.
First permanent Dutch trading post is established in Banten, West Java. First successful VOC privateering raid on a Portuguese ship.

A second English East India Company voyage commanded by Sir Henry Middleton reaches Ternate, Tidore, Ambon and Banda. Fierce VOC hostility is encountered in Banda thus beginning Anglo-Dutch competition for access to spices
Tokugawa Ieyasu passes the title of Shogun to his son, Tokugawa Hidetada, and "retires" to Sunpu.
Gunpowder Plot failed in England.
The fortresses of Veszprém and Visegrad are retaken by the Ottomans.
February, The VOC in alliance with Hitu prepare to attack a Portuguese fort in Ambon but the Portuguese surrender.
Panembahan Seda ing Krapyak of Mataram establishes control over Demak, former center of the Demak Sultanate.
The King of Gowa, a Makassarese kingdom in South Sulawesi, converts to Islam
The Long War between the Ottoman Empire and Austria is ended with the Peace of Zsitvatorok—Austria abandons Transylvania.
Treaty of Vienna ends anti-Habsburg uprising in Royal Hungary.
Assassination of Stephen Bocskay of Transylvania.
Time of Troubles Vasili IV becomes Tzar of Russia.
The Dutch East India Company enters into an alliance with the Johor Sultanate to attack Portuguese Malacca, but they are repelled.
Captain Willem Janszoon and his crew aboard the Dutch East India Company ship Duyfken becomes the first recorded Europeans to sight and make landfall in Australia.
A Spanish fleet occupies Ternate and Tidore.
Jamestown, Virginia, is settled as what would become the first permanent English colony in North America.
Flight of the Earls (the fleeing of most of the native Gaelic aristocracy) occurs from County Donegal in the west of Ulster in Ireland.
Iskandar Muda becomes the Sultan of Aceh (r. 1607–1637). He will launch a series of naval conquests that will transform Aceh into a great power in the western Malay Archipelago.
Quebec City founded by Samuel de Champlain in New France (present-day Canada).
The Dutch East India Company establishes a settlement in Siamese Ayutthaya.
The Netherlands and Spain agree to a Twelve Years' Truce in the Eighty Years' War.
Maximilian of Bavaria establishes the Catholic League.
The Dutch East India Company establishes a factory in Hirado, Japan. VOC traders also make forays into South Sulawesi and Banjarmasin, Borneo.
Pedro de Peralta, governor of New Mexico, establishes the settlement of Santa Fe.
The Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth army defeats combined Russian- Swedish forces at the Battle of Klushino and conquers Moscow.

The VOC appoints Pieter Both as its first Governor-General to enable firmer control of their affairs in Asia. Previously all business had (in theory) required the approval of the Heeren XVII, a group of seventeen shareholders in Amsterdam.
Ottoman Grand Vizier Kuyucu Murad Pasha is able to crush the major remnants of the Jelali Revolts, bringing an end to general anarchy in Anatolia.
Matteo Ricci dies in Beijing.
Panembahan Seda ing Krapyak of Mataram in Central Java attacks Surabaya, a major power on the north coast.
King Henry IV of France is assassinated by François Ravaillac.
The Pontifical and Royal University of Santo Tomas, the oldest existing university in Asia, established by the Dominican Order in Manila

The English establish trading posts at Sukadana (southwest Kalimantan), Makassar, Jayakarta and Jepara in Java, and Aceh, Pariaman and Jambi in (Sumatra) threatening Dutch ambitions for a monopoly on East Indies trade.
The Kingdom of Gowa ends its major push to convert the Makassarese and Bugis in South Sulawesi to Islam.
The Dutch establish a post at Jayakarta (later 'Batavia' and then 'Jakarta').
A Dutch trader is killed in Banjarmasin and the Dutch East India Trading Company sacks the city.
The first publication of the King James Bible.
Sultan Iskandar Muda of Aceh captures the North Sumatran port of Deli.
The Time of Troubles in Russia ends with the establishment of the House of Romanov, which rules until 1917.
Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth is invaded by the Tatars dozens of times.
The Dutch expel the Portuguese from their Solor fort, but won't stay for long.
The Dutch East India Company makes its first forays into Timor.

Sultan Iskandar Muda of Aceh captures the North Sumatran port of Aru, subjugating the Sultanate of Deli. This allows Aceh to focus its expansionary efforts on the Straits of Malacca. Iskandar Muda continues on to sack Johor and kidnap its Sultan's family, but is later forced to retreat back to Aceh.

The Dutch East India Company is forced to evacuate Gresik because of the Mataram siege of neighboring Surabaya. The VOC enters into negotiations with Mataram and is allowed to set up a trading post in Jepara.
Panembahan Seda ing Krapyak of Mataram dies and is succeeded by his son.
John Napier publishes Mirifici Logarithmorum Canonis Descriptio, the first table of logarithms.
Sultan Iskandar Muda of Aceh sinks a Portuguese fleet off of Bintan Island.
The Battle of Osaka (last major threat to Tokugawa Shogunate) ends.
A Dutch East India Company attack on Portuguese Malacca is repelled.
The Portuguese stop hiring Japanese mercenaries after a brawl in Malacca.
Panembahan ing Alaga of Mataram conquers the Eastern Salient of Java (the heartland of the old Majapahit Empire).
The Dutch East India Company is in open hostilities with the Kingdom of Gowa, South Sulawesi.
The last remaining Moriscos (Moors who had nominally converted to Christianity) in Spain are expelled.
Death of retired Shogun Tokugawa Ieyasu.
English poet and playwright William Shakespeare dies.
Sultan Iskandar Muda of Aceh conquers Pahang on the South China Sea.
Panembahan ing Alaga of Mataram puts down a major revolt in Pajang.
The Defenestration of Prague.
The Bohemian Revolt precipitates the Thirty Years' War, which devastates Europe in the years 1618–48.
Bethlen Gabor, Prince of Transylvania joins Protestant Rebels.
The Manchus start invading China. Their conquest eventually topples the Ming Dynasty.
Dispute leads to the execution of Dutchmen in Mataram-controlled Jepara.
Bethlen Gabor is defeated outside Vienna.

Jan Pieterszoon Coen appointed Governor-General of the VOC who would show he had no scruples about using brute force to establish the VOC on a firm footing. While Ambon and Pattani had been the major VOC trading centers to this point, Coen is convinced that Dutch need a more central location near the Sunda Strait.

Dutch East India Company, English East India Company, and Sultanate of Banten all fighting over port city of Jayakarta. VOC forces storm the city and withstand a months-long siege by the combined English, Bantenese, and Jayakartan forces. They are relieved by Jan Pieterszoon Coen and a fleet of nineteen ships out of Ambon. Coen had burned Jepara and its EIC post along the way. The VOC levels the old city of Jayakarta and builds its new headquarters, Batavia, on top of it.
Emperor Ferdinand II defeats the Bohemian rebels in the Battle of White Mountain.
The Brownist Pilgrims arrive in the Mayflower at Cape Cod.
Polish-Ottoman War over Moldavia.
Bethlen Gabor allies with the Ottomans and an invasion of Moldavia takes place. The Polish suffer a disaster at Cecora on the River Prut.
Almost the entire native population of Banda Islands was deported, driven away, starved to death or killed in an attempt to replace them with Dutch colonial slave labour.
Diplomatic agreements in Europe commence a three-year period of cooperation between the Dutch and the English over the spice trade.
The Battle of Chocim
Poles and Cossacks under Jan Karol Chodkiewicz defeat the Ottomans.
Capture of Ormuz; The island of Hormuz was captured by an Anglo-Persian force from Portuguese.
Jamestown massacre
Algonquian natives kill 347 English settlers outside Jamestown, Virginia (one-third of the colony's population) and burn the Henricus settlement.
Maffeo Barberini is elected Pope Urban VIII at the Papal conclave of 1623.

In a notorious but disputed incident, known as the 'Amboyna massacre', ten English and ten Japanese traders are arrested, tried and beheaded for conspiracy against the Dutch Government. The English quietly withdraw from most of their Indonesian activities (except trading in Bantam) and focus on other Asian interests.
As chief minister, Cardinal Richelieu centralises power in France.
The Dutch West India Company invades the Portuguese colony of Bahia in Brazil.
New Amsterdam founded by the Dutch West India Company in North America.
St. Peter's Basilica in the Vatican completed.
Cardinal Richelieu lays siege to Protestant La Rochelle, which eventually capitulates.
Aurochs go extinct.
Sultan Agung of Mataram launched a failed campaign to conquer Dutch Batavia.
Abbas I, the Safavids king, died.
Cardinal Richelieu allies with Swedish Protestant forces in the Thirty Years' War to counter Ferdinand II's expansion.
Iskandar Muda of Aceh Sultanate launched a failed attempt to take Portuguese Malacca.
The Dutch West India Company invades the Portuguese colony of Pernambuco and founds Dutch Brazil.
Mount Vesuvius erupts.
Battle of Lützen, death of king of Sweden Gustav II Adolf.
Taj Mahal building work started in Agra, India.
Galileo Galilei arrives in Rome for his trial before the Inquisition.
Japan transforms into "locked country".
Battle of Nördlingen results in Catholic victory.
Emperor Fasilides expels the Catholic Patriarch Afonso Mendes and several Jesuit missionaries from Ethiopia.
Emperor Fasilides founds the city of Gondar, which becomes the capital of Ethiopia for the next two centuries.
Harvard University is founded in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
The Portuguese are expelled again from their Solor fort by the Dutch following a reoccupation.
Shimabara Rebellion of Japanese Christians, rōnin and peasants against Edo.
René Descartes publishes "Discours de la Méthode" ("The Discourse on the Method") in French.
The first opera house, Teatro San Cassiano, opens in Venice.
Qing dynasty attacked Joseon dynasty.
Naval Battle of the Downs – Republic of the United Provinces fleet decisively defeats a Spanish fleet in English waters.
Disagreements between the Farnese and Barberini Pope Urban VIII escalate into the Wars of Castro and last until 1649.
Wars of the Three Kingdoms, civil wars throughout Scotland, Ireland, and England.
King Charles was compelled to summon Parliament due to the revolt of the Scots.
The Portuguese Restoration War led to the end of the Iberian Union.
Torture is outlawed in England.
The Tokugawa Shogunate institutes Sakoku- foreigners are expelled and no one is allowed to enter or leave Japan.
The Irish Rebellion.
René Descartes publishes Meditationes de prima philosophia Meditations on First Philosophy.
5th Dalai Lama swept power in Tibet, he established the theocratic state in Tibet after series battles against regional Kingdoms.
Dutch explorer Abel Janszoon Tasman achieves the first recorded European sighting of New Zealand.
Beginning of English Civil War, conflict will end in 1651 with the execution of King Charles I, abolishment of the monarchy and the establishment of the supremacy of Parliament over the king.
Giovanni Battista Pamphili is elected Pope Innocent X at the Papal conclave of 1644.
The Manchu conquer China ending the Ming Dynasty. The subsequent Qing Dynasty rules until 1912.
The Mauritanian Thirty-Year War.
The death of Miyamoto Musashi, legendary Japanese Samurai warrior, of natural causes.
Ottoman war with Venice. The Ottomans invade Crete and capture Canea.
Sultan Agung of Mataram dies – and is buried at his graveyard at Imogiri
Seven-year-old Mehmed IV becomes sultan.
The Great Plague of Seville.
The Peace of Westphalia ends the Thirty Years' War and the Eighty Years' War and marks the ends of Spain and the Holy Roman Empire as major European powers.
Fronde civil war in France.
The Khmelnytsky Uprising – a Cossack rebellion in Ukraine which turned into a Ukrainian war of liberation from Poland.
The Deluge wars leave Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in ruins.
The Ottomans capture Crete from the Venetians after the Siege of Candia.
King Charles I is executed for High treason, the first and only English king to be subjected to legal proceedings in a High Court of Justice and put to death.
The Cromwellian conquest of Ireland.
Francesco Redi challenges the theory of spontaneous generation by demonstrating that maggots come from eggs of flies.
English Civil War ends with the Parliamentarian victory at the Battle of Worcester.
Cape Town founded by the Dutch East India Company in South Africa.
Mehmed Köprülü is Grand Vizier.
The Northern Wars cement Sweden's rise as a Great Power.
After his father Shah Jahan completes the Taj Mahal, his son Aurangzeb deposes him as ruler of the Mughal Empire.
The Commonwealth of England ends and the monarchy is brought back during the English Restoration.
Royal Society of London for the Improvement of Natural Knowledge founded.
Mehmed Köprülü dies and is succeeded by his son Ahmed.
The reign of the Kangxi Emperor of China begins.
Cardinal Mazarin, de-facto ruler of France, dies.
Koxinga captures Taiwan from the Dutch and founds the Kingdom of Tungning, which rules until 1683.
Jacques Aymar-Vernay, who later reintroduced Dowsing into popular use in Europe, is born.
Ottoman war against Habsburg Hungary.
France takes full political and military control over its colonial possessions in New France.
Robert Hooke discovers cells using a microscope.
The Battle of St. Gotthard count Raimondo Montecuccoli defeats the Ottomans. The Peace of Vasvar – intended to keep the peace for 20 years.
British troops capture New Amsterdam and rename it New York.
John Evelyn's forestry book, Sylva, is published in England.
The Great Plague of London.
Portugal defeats the Kongo Empire at the Battle of Mbwila.
The Second Anglo-Dutch War fought between England and the United Provinces.
The Great Shivaji-Agra Visit
The Great Fire of London.
The Raid on the Medway during the Second Anglo-Dutch War.
The War of Devolution; France invades the Netherlands. The Peace of Aix-la-Chapelle (1668) brings this to a halt.
The Great Turkish War halts the Ottoman Empire's expansion into Europe.

As a result of the Treaty of Breda between Dutch and England, the Dutch secured a worldwide monopoly on nutmeg by forcing England to give up their claim on Run, the most remote of the Banda Islands. While the Dutch did not press their claims on New Netherland.
Peace Treaty of Lisbon between Spain and Portugal recognizes Portugal as independent country.
The Ottomans capture Crete.
The Hudson's Bay Company is founded in Canada.
The city of Charleston is founded in present-day South Carolina.
Ottoman campaign to help the Ukrainian Cossacks. John Sobieski defeats the Ottomans at the second battle of Khotyn (1673).
Polish-Ottoman War.
Rampjaar in the Netherlands – Combined attack by France, England and two German states on the Republic of the United Provinces.
Lynching of Johan de Witt and his brother Cornelis de Witt in the Hague – William III of Orange takes power.
Franco-Dutch War.
Antoni van Leeuwenhoek is the first to observe microbes with a homemade microscope, using samples he collected from his teeth scrapings, raindrops, and his own feces. He calls them "animalcules."
The Treaty of Westminster ends the war between England and the Republic of the United Provinces.
Maratha Empire founded in India by Shivaji.
The Treaty of Zurawno brings Polish-Ottoman hostilities to a halt.
Kara Mustafa becomes Grand Vizier.
Russia and the Ottoman Empire commence the Russo-Turkish Wars.
The Treaty of Nijmegen ends various interconnected wars among France, the Dutch Republic, Spain, Brandenburg, Sweden, Denmark, the Prince-Bishopric of Münster, and the Holy Roman Empire.
The Pueblo Revolt drives the Spanish out of New Mexico until 1692.
The Pasha of Buda supports Imre Thököly's rebellion in Hungary.
Sultan Mehmed IV, advised by Kara Mustafa, decides to disregard the existing peace treaty with Leopold I, due to expire in 1684.
The Ottomans make camp at Adrianople.
Peter the Great becomes joint ruler of Russia (sole tsar in 1696).
